title: 110_s1960
content: The "Surety Bond Improvement Act of 2007" defines terms like "Administrator" and "Administration" as the Small Business Administration. It also addresses the regulations and requirements related to surety bonds. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to increase the maximum amount for surety bonds and authorize the use of approved rates by the insurance commissioner. Additionally, the payment of guarantees under the Act is revised to include indemnification provisions. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to revise the conditions for guarantees, including the maximum amount and payment provisions. Additionally, reports to Congress are required for proposed fee changes under the Act. The Administrator must report to Congress and the public on the basis for fee changes under the Small Business Investment Act of 1958. The report should include study contents and details on fees received versus program costs. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 requires the Administrator to report to Congress on fee changes. Congress acknowledges that the program may operate at a loss and is not required to be self-funding. SEC. 4. MEDIATION. The Administrator must establish regulations for a nonbinding, neutral, third-party alternative dispute resolution process between sureties and the Administration. The regulations should allow either party to request mediation, outline the selection of a mediator, set a time frame for mediation, and determine cost-sharing. The method for sharing mediation costs between a participating surety and the Administration is defined in this section. Definitions include "issue in controversy," "participating surety," and "surety."
